subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... Quite so.  I was entirely serious in saying that if Wells says something, then I do indeed believe it. ... Chree for tree probably isn t a speech
messageBody:
Paige Gabhart scripsit:

> I did not mean to imply that Wells had all the answers, merely that he
> appears to be an acknowledged expert in the field, which I am not, and I
> was passing on what he told me regarding the substitution of "chr" for "tr."

Quite so. I was entirely serious in saying that if Wells says something,
then I do indeed believe it.

> The point I was getting at is that although there is a tremendous
> variation in spoken English from one dialect to another, there is a
> distinction which I feel needs to be made between spelling according to
> one's dialect and spelling according to a speech pathology (if that is
> the appropriate term), such as a lisp.

Chree for tree probably isn't a speech pathology, just an idiosyncratic
substitution. Sometimes the line can be a fine one.

--
John Cowan cowan@... http://ccil.org/~cowan
In the sciences, we are now uniquely privileged to sit side by side
with the giants on whose shoulders we stand.
--Gerald Holton
